Security culture refers to the set of values that determines how people within an organisation are expected to think about and approach security. The extent to which an organisation has good security is indicated by its security culture.
All organisations need employees, suppliers and other colleagues to behave in a way that helps ensure good security at all times.
Getting security culture right promotes the desired security behaviours that helps develop a security-conscious workforce.
The is creating a portfolio of security culture resources to help supplement the formal policy and guidance material.

body.p: Sections 6.3 Cyber security and 6.4 Technical security of the standard state:

ul.li: The purpose of cyber security is to ensure the security of data and information. To operate effectively, the UK government needs to maintain the confidentiality, integrity and availability of its information, systems and infrastructure, and the services it provides.

The purpose of technical security measures is to holistically protect sensitive information and technology from close access acquisition or exploitation by hostile actors, as well as any other form of technical manipulation. Technical security also relates to the protection of security systems from compromise and/or external interference.
